text: are you one of the lucky people who has
like a huge raspberry bush in their
neighborhood or a peach tree on their
property and you have all this fruit in
the summer you don't know what to do
with it I am NOT one of those people but
I still love making jam and I do it
every summer because I'm a bit of a
summer addict so today I'm going to show
you how to make jam
works with many many kinds of fruit I'm
using raspberry but I've added to my pot
it's three pounds or twelve cups of
raspberries three pounds of fruit and I
have one and a half pounds or four and a
half cups of sugar and I'm combining
those two things in a pot together Jam
is actually really really simple a lot
of people are kind of afraid to make jam
but you should not be because actually
one of the simplest things to do and I
don't even use any additional pectin so
my jam only has four ingredients fruit
sugar salt and lemon juice I'm going to
add about a pinch of salt big pinch
coarse salt and then the juice of half
of the lemons if you were using any
other kind of berry we would do the same
exact thing just squeeze the lemon juice
in and that's all your ingredients mash
it a bit with a potato masher just to
start to get the juices going and then
what you need to do is just bring this
to a boil this is starting to come to a
boil and as you can see it's getting
kind of aggressive make sure that when
you're making jam you use a pot that's
big enough because it will boil up quite
aggressively in the beginning what you
want to do for the beginning part of
cooking your jam is to cook it until
it's boiling in a boil that will not be
stirred down as you can see when I just
start it it stopped boiling it's not
boiling enough yet you also want to make
sure not only that your pot is big
enough but also that it is a nice heavy
bottomed pot you don't want your Jam to
scorch on the bottom all of that sugar
and that fruit could cause problems
see how it's boiling and I'm stirring it
and it's not subsiding that's the kind
of boiling that I'm talking about once
it gets to this point it should take
another ten or twelve minutes and you
really want to stand here stirring it
and what's gonna happen is slowly these
recive like bubbles will subside a
little bit you'll start to see the fruit
on the top and it'll be really nice and
thick there's this foam on the top
you're going to want to remove that
before you put it into the jars or
whatever you're going to store it and I
generally don't skim too much in the
beginning because some of what looks
like foam is really just bubbles when
you cook jam and such small batches
doesn't take that long so it goes from
being just a bunch of hot fruit to being
jam in a matter of minutes now I am
going to start skimming a little bit of
the foam off I just like to use a metal
spoon with a really thin edge to skim
off the foam it's already starting to
get much much thicker the bubbles are
kind of more slow a little molten lava
like you can test this with a candy
thermometer it should be 220 degrees I
like to just use the spoon method if
there are two drops coming off of your
spoon they'll come together and they'll
form a sheet dropping off or you can
test it on a cold plate you put the
plates in the freezer put a little jam
on there when you push your finger
through it it'll make a little path so
now you're starting to see a lot of the
seeds on the top the mixture is moving
much more slowly when you move your
spoon through it's very close to being
jammed this is totally different than
making jelly it's not the same process
really and many fruits don't actually
have enough pectin to make jelly on
their own but they will make jam because
there's all of these solids in there
that help thicken it it's done you guys
I'm gonna turn this off because in
slaughtering me so much but look so I'm
holding up the spoon and it's dropping
off it's dropping off and then all of a
sudden at the end it drops off and it
makes a sheet its gelled it's done
sometimes it doesn't sheet the way that
it's supposed to if you look it up I the
the ball preserving books all the time
and their website fresh preserving calm
it's the best resource for all of your
canning needs also anyway they have
really cool diagrams of what it looks
like when it's cheating that's all
alright so here's the plate with the jam
on it was in the freezer for just a
minute as you can see I'm putting my
finger through it it's not only
wrinkling but it's leaving a little path
that's another way to that you know your
jam is done Oh camera my fingers now
it's time to jar them up
I'm gonna put them in ball jars if
you're not going to be caning them if
you're gonna put them in the freezer any
freezer safe container will do I want to
strain some of the seeds out of the jam
because red raspberries have a lot of
seeds it isn't necessary it's just
something that I like to do so I usually
take a little less than half or half of
the jam and then just pass it through a
fine sieve to remove them I turned this
off and yet it is still boiling that's
how hot it is so be careful removing
some of the seeds does reduce the yield
on your Jam a little bit but it gives a
nice consistency scrape off the bottom
get all the men back in combine this
back with the rest of your jam and now
you can put it into your jars or
whatever you're going to store it in if
you're planning on freezing it like I
said make sure that they're freezer safe
jars you're putting it in plastic I
recommend letting it cool a little bit
before you put it in but I'm going to
put mine in jars which I have washed and
I've sterilized by oiling them for 10
minutes you lift one jar out at a time
if you're going to seal them by
sterilizing them in the boiling water
bath and storing them on your shelf you
need to make sure that they're
sterilized you need to make sure they're
hot you add your hot jam to your hot jar
you fill them leaving a half-inch
headspace and then once you've filled
your jar you want to clean the top to
make sure that there's no Jam on it
whatsoever so use a damp hot towel and
then bring your lids these kinds of
canning jars have a double lid system
the top and then the screw that holds it
in place you want to remove your top
from hot water they've also been
sterilized place it on top of your jar
and then use your screw to hold it in
place it shouldn't be too tight it's
just there to hold this in place until
the jar seals which you ensure that it
will seal by returning it to your
boiling water needs to be covered by a
full inch and you need to boil it for 10
minutes that's if you want these to be
shelf stable if you're not going to be
processing it to be
shelf-stable you want to make sure that
the jam cools a little bit before you
cover it up otherwise it might seal on
its own and then you don't really know
what's going on so this is what I do for
that I'm not going to lie I actually
like it better in the freezer I find
that it stays fresher longer even though
it's shelf stable for up to a year when
you process it in a boiling water bath I
find that it dis colors a little bit and
the flavors not as fresh so if you have
room in your freezer that's what I like
to do with my jam so I take it I fill my
jars leave a half an inch of headspace
and then I cool it uncovered and then I
cover it up same way put the lids on
screw them on and then label them and
put them in the fridge once they cooled
down enough to put in your freezer or
refrigerator or you process them make
sure that you save yourself at least one
jar to start eating immediately because
you are going to want to and hopefully
you can make enough to last you all year
long
